text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 8.26.1, Alternative Dispute Resolution, Fast Track Settlement for Large Business and International (LB&I) Taxpayers.
The revision to this IRM contains several editorial
This IRM revision supersedes IRM 8.26.1 dated September 21,

(10-01-2012) What to Know About LB&I FTS
If the LB&I FTS process is unsuccessful in resolving an issue, a taxpayer is not precluded from requesting traditional Appeals consideration.
Appeals has settlement authority under Delegation Order 8–3 found in IRM 1.2.47, Delegation of Authorities for the Appeals Process.
Potential settlement positions discussed with the taxpayer before an LB&I FTS referral are presented to the ATCL or Appeals Officer (AO) for consideration

Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) during the session. However, Appeals does an independent evaluation of hazards and does not execute a settlement if it does not fall within such ation or established settlement guidelines for the issue. (
) If the ATCL or AO does not accept a settlement proposed between the taxpayer and LB&I, he/she explains why it is not acceptable to both parties. (

) If a Joint Committee report is required for the case, Appeals delays of the closing agreement until LB&I completes the Joint Committee proce- dures. Where Appeals settlement authority is utilized on a Joint Committee case, the ATCL or AO involved in the settlement is available to respond to inquiries from the Joint Committee regarding the settlement. (

) In LB&I FTS, ATCLs and AOs are not acting in their traditional Appeals ment role. As a result, the prohibition on ex parte communications between in LB&I FTS Appeals and other Internal Revenue Service employees provided by
) of the Internal Revenue Service Restructuring and Reform Act of
does not apply to the communications in the process. (

) Appeals may not issue a statutory notice of deficiency. (cid:
) Information disclosed by the taxpayer to LB&I during the FTS session be used by LB&I to complete the examination report. (cid:
) The taxpayer retains all traditional appeal rights. (

of Rev. Proc.
and IRM
for tion on ex parte for FTS. (

) Appeals and LB&I jointly manage and administer the LB&I FTS Program. (
) The program enables taxpayers and the IRS to work together to resolve standing issues while the case remains in the jurisdiction of LB&I. (

) It provides LB&I and taxpayers an opportunity to resolve their disputes with ATCL or AO providing mediation skills and settlement authority. The techniques used focus issues and lead LB&I and the taxpayer to self- determine the outcome of the dispute. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

8.26.1.3.1 (10-01-2012) Ex Parte in LB&I FTS Cases

a. LB&I FTS allows the parties to consider hazards regarding what facts, if any, a court will accept and hazards regarding the merits of different possible legal interpretations of law in resolving disputes. b. Where the disposition of an issue involves consideration of the hazards of litigation, Appeals exercises delegated settlement authority to accept the settlement in a closing agreement that finally determines the treatment of the issues.
While settlement authority is available in the process, the issues are often resolved in a mediated agreement between the taxpayer and Examination.
LB&I FTS takes place while the case is in LB&I’s jurisdiction and the process is designed to be completed in approximately 120 calendar days.
Settlement for Large Business and (LB&I) Taxpayers
) LB&I FTS is designed to: (cid:
) Increase issue resolution at the lowest level. (cid:
) Use Appeals tools in Exam. (cid:
) Decrease the overall time from return filing to ultimate resolution. (cid:
) Reduce the burden for the taxpayer and the Service. (

) Parties to the Process: a. The decision makers must fully participate in the LB&I FTS process. b. The decision makers decide who to invite to the LB&I FTS session. c. The parties are encouraged to bring their best experts into the This includes Technical Advisors in those instances where the issues industry specific, or where a Technical Advisory position was for the issue. (

) All three parties - LB&I, the taxpayer, and Appeals - are active participants the process, and all three must agree before a proposed resolution is mented. When a resolution is not reached through mediation, Appeals may propose a resolution, but that proposal is not imposed on either party. (
) All “decision-makers” are required to be present. (
) LB&I is fully involved in the LB&I FTS process as an equal participant. (
) LB&I participants include the LB&I Team Manager, Revenue Agents and in the who have the knowledge and expertise to contribute to issue resolution. (
) In addition to the Team Manager, LB&I participants generally include the Coordinator and/or Revenue Agents primarily responsible for the of the subject issue(s). (

) LB&I participants also include Specialists and/or Technical Advisors. In instances where the issues are industry specific or there is a Technical Advisory position established for the issue, the participation of appropriate Technical Advisors is strongly recommended. (
) The LB&I Team Manager, in consultation with the assigned ATCL or AO, mines the LB&I participants. (

) For CAP issues, LB&I participants include the Team Manager, and the Account Coordinator (AC), as well as any Specialists and/or Technical Advisors, if needed. If necessary, the LB&I Territory Manager and the of Field Operations also participate in the FTS process. (

) Within ten business days after assignment of the case, the ATCL or AO the taxpayer and the LB&I Team Manager to start the FTS session Role in process and follows-up in writing with an FTS Acknowledgement Letter. ATCL or AO should document the case activity record when these actions have been taken. (
) The ATCL or AO identifies and discusses the need to limit the number of ticipants in the FTS session. (
) Internal Revenue Manual

Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) (
) LB&I FTS cases are excluded from the Settlement Authority Panel Review, because LB&I must agree to any disposition of the issues. (
) Where an issue is coordinated, the ATCL or AO follows the procedures in
, Coordinated and Appeals Emerging Issues. (

) To meet the requirements that all decision-makers attend the LB&I FTS session, and that coordinated issues be reviewed by the Appeals Domestic Technical /International Technical Specialist, the Appeals Technical Specialist Role in serves as a team member and participates in the FTS session with the Issues taxpayer and LB&I. (

) If the Appeals Technical Specialist is not part of the Fast Track Team, ment of the coordinated issue remains subject to the review and of the Appeals Technical Specialist. This is accomplished via telephone sion, review and concurrence. (
) If there is a disagreement between the Appeals Technical Specialist and ATCL or AO on appropriate settlement terms for the issue, follow the procedures in IRM
, Review and Concurrence Procedures. (

) LB&I FTS is generally available for all cases worked under the jurisdiction LB&I. However, it is not the appropriate dispute resolution process for all Cases involving LB&I taxpayers. The LB&I Group Manager or designee and the into LB&I FTS taxpayer must evaluate their individual circumstances to determine if this process meets their needs. (
) Appeals Coordinated Issues (ACIs), Compliance Coordinated Issues Industry Specialization Program (ISP) Issues and listed transactions are accepted into LB&I FTS. (

) Bankruptcy cases are accepted when LB&I follows the IRM provisions regarding notification to Chief Counsel and the Justice Department. Cases in a. Appeals provides an ATCL or AO to assist Examination and the in evaluating the merits of the issues, including hazards of litigation. b. Since the final tax determination is generally under the jurisdiction of a court, a closing agreement is generally not used because no one senting the taxpayer possesses the authority to execute the closing agreement. The decision to reduce the liability in the proof of claim with LB&I, in accordance with Chief Counsel and the Justice (
) TEFRA cases are accepted under limited circumstances with the of both the Appeals Fast Track Program Manager and the LB&I Territory Cases in LB&I Manager. (
) LB&I FTS is used for cases in a TEFRA proceeding where the first level nership and the major controlling partners are included in the FTS session. (

) LB&I must agree to maintain responsibility for both the partnership and the partner statutes, and to complete the required TEFRA administrative ings, including NOPA, NBAP and FPAA procedures, and to secure and partner settlement agreements for all levels.
8.26 Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR)
LB&I FTS cases are excluded from the Settlement Authority Panel Review, because LB&I must agree to any disposition of the issues.
Bankruptcy cases are accepted when LB&I follows the IRM provisions regarding notification to Chief Counsel and the Justice Department.

Appeals provides an ATCL or AO to assist Examination and the taxpayer in evaluating the merits of the issues, including hazards of litigation. Since the final tax determination is generally under the jurisdiction of a court, a closing agreement is generally not used because no one repre

senting the taxpayer possesses the authority to execute the closing agreement. The decision to reduce the liability in the proof of claim rests with LB&I, in accordance with Chief Counsel and the Justice Department.
TEFRA cases are accepted under limited circumstances with the concurrence of both the Appeals Fast Track Program Manager and the LB&I Territory
LB&I FTS is used for cases in a TEFRA proceeding where the first level part- nership and the major controlling partners are included in the FTS session.

) An ATCL or AO conducts the FTS session at the first entity level and helps parties reach a settlement. (
) Secure the following Waiver on Assessment agreements from the partners: a. For partnership tax years ending before
, secure Form
-P, Agreement to Assessment and Collection of Deficiency in Tax for ship Adjustments, or Form
-P(AD) , Settlement Agreement for Partnership Adjustments, whichever is appropriate. b. For partnership tax years ending after

-PT, Agreement for Partnership Items & Partnership Level Determinations as Penalties, Additions to Tax, and Additional Amounts, or Form Settlement Agreement for Partnership Items and Partnership Level minations as to Penalties, Additions to Tax, and Additional Amounts, whichever is appropriate. (
) Generally, a closing agreement is not used in TEFRA cases, but may be at the option of the parties. Refer to IRM
for guidance in closing agreements for partners in a TEFRA partnership. (
) The Appeals Official signs Form
-P(AD) or Form

-PT(AD) for all partners when he/she uses the settlement authority delegated to him/her to resolve issues based on an analysis of the hazards of litigation. If an Official does not use his/her settlement authority, LB&I secures Form
-P Form

-PT from all partners. Caution: If the correct allocation of a partnership interest is an issue being ered, do not accept any settlement agreements unless all partners to the allocation by executing appropriate agreement forms. See IRM
for more information on allocation issues. (
) FTS is available on an issue-by-issue basis for LB&I cases participating in Compliance Assurance Process (CAP). The IRS formally announced CAP in Announcement

I.R.B. CAP is an LB&I program designed in resolve tax issues prior to the filing of a tax return. a. Under CAP, corporations are assigned to an LB&I Account Coordinator (AC) who works with the taxpayer and coordinates additional IRS resources as needed to resolve economic events and material tax tions in a contemporaneous manner with the goal of resolving tax prior to filing the corporate tax return. b. The LB&I AC engages the taxpayer to identify and resolve material during the tax year rather than waiting several years after a tax return is filed. c. When an agreement to the proper tax treatment is reached, the receives an acceptance letter from the IRS, omitting the need for post filing review of specific transactions or issues. (

) For LB&I taxpayers participating in CAP who do not utilize FTS prior to the return being filed, the option is available to elect FTS during the post-filing amination process. An exception is a change in facts and circumstances the parties subsequently agree merits the use of FTS.
An ATCL or AO conducts the FTS session at the first entity level and helps the parties reach a settlement.

for more information on allocation issues. (
) FTS is available on an issue-by-issue basis for LB&I cases participating in the Compliance Assurance Process (CAP). The IRS formally announced CAP in Announcement

The LB&I AC engages the taxpayer to identify and resolve material during the tax year rather than waiting several years after a tax return is filed. c. When an agreement to the proper tax treatment is reached, the taxpayer receives an acceptance letter from the IRS, omitting the need for post filing review of specific transactions or issues. (

(10-01-2012) Compliance Assurance Process (CAP) Cases in LB&I FTS

a. Under CAP, corporations are assigned to an LB&I Account Coordinator (AC) who works with the taxpayer and coordinates additional IRS resources as needed to resolve economic events and material tax tions in a contemporaneous manner with the goal of resolving tax issues prior to filing the corporate tax return. b. The LB&I AC engages the taxpayer to identify and resolve material issues during the tax year rather than waiting several years after a tax return is filed. c. When an agreement to the proper tax treatment is reached, the taxpayer receives an acceptance letter from the IRS, omitting the need for post filing review of specific transactions or issues. For LB&I taxpayers participating in CAP who do not utilize FTS prior to the

For LB&I taxpayers participating in CAP who do not utilize FTS prior to the return being filed, the option is available to elect FTS during the post-filing amination process. An exception is a change in facts and circumstances the parties subsequently agree merits the use of FTS.
8.26 Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR)
The appropriate non-LB&I Examination Operating Division carries the responsibilities of the LB&I Team Manager.
) Generally, docketed cases, constitutional issues, and cases in which a letter was issued are excluded from the LB&I FTS program. (

) LB&I FTS is not available for the following: FTS a. Issues in a taxpayer’s case designated for litigation. b. Issues in a taxpayer’s case under consideration for designation for tion. c. Issues for which a taxpayer requests the Simultaneous tent Authority procedure described in section
of Rev. Proc.

d. Issues outside of LB&I jurisdiction (e.g. Collection, Employee Plans, Exempt Organizations) except as noted above. e. Issues that are part of a whipsaw transaction. f. Issues identified in a Chief Counsel Notice, or equivalent publication, excluded from the FTS process. g. Issues for which mediation is not consistent with sound tax (
) Issues specifically excluded under Rev. Proc.
result in the the entire case. (
) LB&I FTS is initiated any time after an issue is fully developed. An issue is generally considered fully developed when - a. For cases from LB&I - when Form

, Notice of Proposed was issued to the taxpayer clearly setting out the Government’s and the taxpayer has prepared a written response defining their and the basis for disagreement. b. For cases from other Operating Divisions - when the case could be written up as unagreed with a
-day or
-day letter. (

) It is best to consider all unagreed issues of a case in one “Application for Track Settlement”; however, depending on the availability of sufficient resources, individual issues may be accepted into LB&I FTS. When it is in best interest of tax administration, accept the “Application for Fast Track ment” for individual issues or groups of issues. (
) The greatest opportunity to reduce administrative burden and costs for all parties exists when
Generally, docketed cases, constitutional issues, and cases in which a 30-day letter was issued are excluded from the LB&I FTS program.

) All issues are raised and the examination process is nearly complete. (cid:

) With the concurrence of the Appeals Fast Track Program Manager and LB&I Territory Manager, an issue is accepted when it is adequately to facilitate resolution, even though it may not be developed to the extent required for a Revenue Agent Report (RAR). (
) When the “Application for Fast Track Settlement”, Form
, is ready to submit and is signed by the appropriate LB&I Territory Manager, the Acceptance LB&I Team Manager emails the application to the FTS mailbox at *AP Case FTS@irs.gov. (
) In most cases, the Appeals Fast Track Program Manager notifies the ATM an LB&I FTS case is coming to the local office. When time permits, the pre-assigns an ATCL or AO to the case. (
) Within three business days of receipt, the Appeals Fast Track Program Manager reviews the “Application for Fast Track Settlement” to determine LB&I FTS eligibility requirements are met. (
) Any case started without concurrence of both the Appeals Fast Track Manager and the Examination Territory Manager will, at the discretion of manager, be treated as a withdrawn case. (
) Except with the concurrence of the LB&I Territory Manager and the Fast Track Program Manager, the FTS process is limited to
days. (
) If the Appeals Fast Track Program Manager determines the case is he/she signs the Application to Fast Track Settlement and forwards it to LB&I FTS local ATM for concurrence. (
) If the ATM concurs with the acceptance of the application, he/she signs “Application for Fast Track Settlement” and faxes a signed copy to the Fast Track Program Manager. (
) Another ATM can be assigned to do the review if the first ATM notifies the Appeals Fast Track Program Manager that he/she does not recommend ceptance. (

) If the Appeals Fast Track Program Manager or ATM determines that a does not qualify for LB&I FTS (e.g. issues not fully developed, issues do LB&I FTS qualify, Appeals resources are not available, issues excluded), the ATM discusses the reason(s) for the denial with the Appeals Fast Track Manager.
Except with the concurrence of the LB&I Territory Manager and the Appeals Fast Track Program Manager, the FTS process is limited to 120 calendar

) Upon acceptance of the “Application for Fast Track Settlement,” and the currence of the Appeals Fast Track Program Manager, the ATM assigns LB&I case to an ATCL or AO within seven business days of receipt of the tion. (
) Use the following general guidelines when assigning cases from LB&I: a. Primarily assign to a Grade
ATCL trained in mediation. b. In limited cases, assign individually to a Grade
AO trained in or assign it jointly to an AO and an Appeals Team Manager (ATM) who as co-mediators. (
) Use the following general guidelines when assigning cases from other Operating Divisions participating in the LB&I FTS program as follows: a. Primarily assign to a Grade
AO trained in mediation in conjunction an ATM. b. In limited cases, assign to a Grade
AO trained in mediation in tion with an ATM. (
) When determining a reasonably convenient site for the LB&I FTS session, ATCL or AO follows the provisions of IRM
for providing conference opportunities. (
) The ATM and ATCL or AO coordinate on the need to use a team of AOs. (
) When the case includes Appeals Coordinated Issues (ACI) or LB&I Coordi- nated Issues (CCI), the ATCL or AO follows the requirements in IRM IRC
, and IRM
, to refer the issues to Appeals Domestic/Interna- tional Operations. Initiate the referral by phone and follow up with a formal written referral. (

) The Appeals LB&I FTS Program Manager requests that Appeals assign the FTS case to ATCLs or AOs with experience or particular expertise in the issue, such as CCI/ACI issues, international issues or transactions. (
) The LB&I FTS session includes all activities from the acceptance date of LB&I FTS case through the date all three parties reach a final agreement. (
) Planning begins when the taxpayer and LB&I complete the “Application for Fast Track Settlement,” which includes a target completion date. (
) The parties must agree to a plan that allows completion of the LB&I FTS process within
calendar days. Internal Revenue Manual

The LB&I FTS session includes all activities from the acceptance date of the LB&I FTS case through the date all three parties reach a final agreement.

8.26 Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR)
Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) (
) The FT Session Report, Form
, assists the parties in planning the LB&I FTS session and reports progress on the issues in dispute. the Session (

) Use the FT Session Report to identify the issues and reflect agreement by all parties on the number and description of issues, the amounts in dispute, ference dates, and a plan of action to follow in the LB&I FTS process. (
) In addition to documenting all contacts in the ACDS activity record and ence notes, the ATCL or AO uses the FT Session Report at the start of the process, and updates it as decisions are made. (
) The ATCL or AO gives the taxpayer and LB&I a copy of the FT Session at the beginning of the process with Letter
, FTS Acknowledgement and after each decision is reached and the report is updated. He/She the parties agree with all entries. (
) At the conclusion of the process, the FT Session Report forms the basis for drafting closing agreements and the Revenue Agent’s Report (RAR). (

) The ATCL or AO solicits signatures of the taxpayer and LB&I Team Manager the conclusion of the session whether agreed or unagreed. Signing the FT Session Report does not constitute a final settlement. The signatures carry more force and effect than a memorandum of understanding between the parties. (

) The FT Session Report is not a waiver of restrictions on assessment, does terminate consents to extend the statute of limitations, nor does it start the running of any statute of limitations, in particular the one-year statute under IRC
(f) involving TEFRA proceedings. (
) LB&I FTS cases involving TEFRA partnerships must include the above language on the face of the FTS Session Report. (
) The signature of a Service official on the FT Session Report does not create promise against reopening the case. (

) When conducting the LB&I FTS session, the ATCL or AO uses a FTS Report and an agenda. The agenda guides the communication, sets the the LB&I of issue discussion, asks questions to clarify each issue and guides confer- ence meetings. (
) The ATCL or AO provides the FTS Session Report to all decision makers in the process, and updates it as the session progresses. (
) The LB&I FTS session is led by Appeals, but all three parties are active pants with equal voices. (
) LB&I FTS employs various alternative dispute resolution techniques to solutions. (
) Appeals does not act in a traditional Appeals role, but first uses an interest- based approach to facilitate a settlement of the issues between the parties. (
) Using mediation techniques, Appeals attempts to bring the parties to a resolution of the issues during the FTS session. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
G
The FT Session Report, Form 14000, assists the parties in planning the LB&I FTS session and reports progress on the issues in dispute.
At the conclusion of the process, the FT Session Report forms the basis for drafting closing agreements and the Revenue Agent’s Report (RAR).
8.26.1.12.2 (10-01-2012) Conducting the LB&I FTS Session
The ATCL or AO provides the FTS Session Report to all decision makers in the process, and updates it as the session progresses.
Appeals does not act in a traditional Appeals role, but first uses an interest- based approach to facilitate a settlement of the issues between the parties.
Using mediation techniques, Appeals attempts to bring the parties to a mutual resolution of the issues during the FTS session.
Track Settlement for Large Business and (LB&I) Taxpayers 8.26.1
(LB&I) Taxpayers

) As issues are resolved, Appeals posts the results to the FTS Session and gives an updated copy to all participants. Appeals maintains a history the updated FTS Session Reports. (
) If the taxpayer or LB&I presents new information during the LB&I FTS Appeals gives the receiving party adequate time to evaluate it. (

) If consideration of substantial new information unacceptably delays the FTS During LB&I session, Appeals withdraws the case from LB&I FTS. The case is for acceptance into LB&I FTS after the issues are fully developed. (
) In situations where substantial new information is disclosed as part of the process, the information serves as a basis to raise a new issue or file a Where the process is not delayed beyond
calendar days, and all agree to accept the new issue or claim, it is accepted into the existing LB&I FTS process. (

) Once a case comes to LB&I FTS, the expectation is that all issues and were raised, all relevant information is disclosed, and the case is ready for resolution. The ATCL or AO confirms all issues are listed on the FTS LB&I FTS Report at the beginning of the process. (
) New issues or claims are generally not accepted if the FTS process cannot completed within
calendar days. (
) The grounds for raising a new issue or claim must be substantial, and the potential effect on the tax liability must be material. New issues or claims not raised to trade against existing issues. (
) A taxpayer’s claim requires LB&I action. However, such action need not be part of the LB&I FTS process. (
) New, unrelated claims or new issues raised are not attached to an existing FTS process, but generally are considered in a separate process outside of FTS. (
) While the parties work to resolve the issues originally referred to LB&I FTS, the process is not suspended to allow examination of the new (

) If the taxpayer declines to bring the LB&I FTS process to a conclusion prior consideration of such claims, the Service withdraws the case from LB&I The taxpayer then reapplies for LB&I FTS after LB&I completes a review of new claim. (

) NEW ISSUES - To raise a new issue, there must be good, sound, grounds already existing in the record or known to the decision maker. Sub- stantial grounds are those that cause a decision maker to be quite certain, the time a new issue is raised, that the Government will prevail if the issue litigated. Quite certain does not necessarily mean
percent certain, but it does mean a very high degree of certainty. (

Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) (

) If after a reasonable time, it is apparent no further benefit will be derived the process, the LB&I Team Manager and/or the ATCL or AO considers LB&I nating the session. If it is determined the session should be terminated, consults the Appeals Fast Track Program Manager before making the final decision to terminate the session. (
) A decision by the LB&I Team Manager to terminate the FTS session requires concurrence of the appropriate LB&I Territory Manager. (
) If no issues are resolved prior to termination, no further reporting to the taxpayer or LB&I by Appeals are required. (
) If some issues are resolved at the time of termination, follow standard LB&I FTS process closing procedures for the resolved issues. (

) The taxpayer retains all standard appeal rights with regard to any issues remaining unresolved at the time of termination. However, the traditional appeal will not be assigned to the same ATCL or AO that heard the FTS session, unless concurrence is received in writing from the taxpayer and prior to assignment. (

) If after assignment, it is determined a case is not ready for the LB&I FTS process, or there is a change in status, the ATCL or AO discusses LB&I of the case with the appropriate Appeals Fast Track Program Manager and Appeals Team Manager. (

) A change in status may include but is not limited to filing for bankruptcy, a change in corporate structure, finding the case is not sufficiently developed proceed, or a determination on a Service-wide basis that a particular issue is not subject to a negotiated settlement. (

) In the event of the withdrawal of a case, the ATCL or AO - a. Sends a letter to both the taxpayer and LB&I identifying who listing the unresolved issues, and explaining that the taxpayer retains rights to a traditional appeal. b. Returns the administrative file to LB&I without an Appeals Case dum (ACM). The file consists only of Form
and the taxpayer’s response to Examination . c. Follows closing procedures listed in IRM
for closing (
) A case may be withdrawn without prejudice, and after the question is addressed, the “Application for Fast Track” may be reconsidered. (

) When resubmitting a withdrawn case, management decides how to assign ATCL or AO. Ex parte restrictions are not imposed on intra-Appeals cations. Appeals management takes appropriate action to fulfill the Appeals Mission to be fair and impartial. This policy must be made clear to the at the beginning of the process, and if the taxpayer is unable to accept this policy, the taxpayer may decide to forego the LB&I FTS option and go to tional Appeals. (
) The taxpayer may withdraw from LB&I FTS at any time by providing written notice to the LB&I Team Manager and the ATCL or AO. (

) When a taxpayer requests an Appeals hearing and submits an acceptable protest, LB&I closes the case as “Unagreed” or “Partially Agreed,” as ate, and forwards the case to Appeals. (
) The taxpayer is advised that the case will be closed using the standard closing process. (
) Appeals uses various methods and techniques to meet the needs and stances of each particular case. (

) The ATCL or AO may make recommendations regarding the settlement of for or all issues (both factual and legal). If acceptable to both parties, the ment proposal is adopted. However, neither party is required to accept a proposal. (

) Both LB&I and the taxpayer must agree with the settlement proposal. If the LB&I Team Manager rejects the ATCL’s or AO’s settlement proposal, the Territory Manager must concur in writing with the rejection. (
) If the LB&I Territory Manager concurs with the LB&I Team Manager’s of the proposed settlement, and an acceptable alternative settlement is not reached, the issue is closed unagreed. (
) If the LB&I Territory Manager does not concur with the rejection of the proposed settlement, the settlement proposal is accepted by LB&I. (

) If an agreement is reached, but a subsequent authoritative decision is Report rendered affecting the agreement in a substantive and material manner, LB&I or Appeals reconsiders the agreement unless both the taxpayer and Appeals previously signed a closing agreement Form
, or Form
-AD. (

) If the change is substantive and material, the agreement is renegotiated. word substantive means a change in law or legal precedent which results in meaningful change to Appeals’ assessment of the hazards of litigation. (
) Any agreement reached in a LB&I FTS session may be reopened in the of fraud, malfeasance, concealment or misrepresentation of a material fact. (
) The grounds for such action must be substantial (strong, possessing real merit) and the potential effect on the tax liability must be material (having importance and great consequence). (
) Outside of these strict parameters, LB&I and Appeals will respect the terms agreed to on the FTS Session Report. (
) LB&I and Appeals commit to advocate the agreement reached in a signed Session Report to reviewing authorities, such as the Joint Committee. (

) In the event of a request from Appeals or LB&I to reconsider the FT Report agreement, the LB&I Territory Manager and the ATM must agree on decision to reconsider. If LB&I and Appeals are unable to agree, the elevated to the Executive owners of the LB&I FTS process. (

) For CAP issues, forward the closing letter to the LB&I AC and LB&I Team Manager. (

) For issues settled using Appeals settlement authority, Appeals prepares a ACM and a closing agreement. A brief ACM summarizes the significant body of law relied upon by the parties, and includes a brief evaluation and ommendation on whether the disposition should be accepted. (

) For issues settled using the authority of the LB&I Team Manager rather than Appeals settlement authority, Appeals does not prepare an ACM. Appeals be asked to assist in preparing a closing agreement for LB&I resolved but an authorized LB&I manager executes the closing agreement. (
) No ACM is required for issues not resolved in the FTS session. (

and includes the following entries: a. Item

) Follow special procedures in cases subject to Joint Committee reporting re- quirements. (

) Upon assignment of an LB&I FTS case, Appeals must confer with both the taxpayer and LB&I to determine whether the case is subject to Joint Committee reporting requirements, and record the results in the ACDS case activity record. (

) At the completion of the LB&I FTS process, the case status relative to Joint Committee reporting is reconfirmed, taking into consideration the results of settlement process, before finalizing the settlement. (
) When issues are resolved by Appeals using delegated settlement authority, Appeals is responsible for preparing an ACM and providing a copy to LB&I inclusion in their Joint Committee Report.

For issues settled using the authority of the LB&I Team Manager rather than Appeals settlement authority, Appeals does not prepare an ACM. Appeals may be asked to assist in preparing a closing agreement for LB&I resolved issues, but an authorized LB&I manager executes the closing agreement.

Upon assignment of an LB&I FTS case, Appeals must confer with both taxpayer and LB&I to determine whether the case is subject to Joint Committee reporting requirements, and record the results in the ACDS activity record. At the completion of the LB&I FTS process, the case status relative to Committee reporting is reconfirmed, taking into consideration the results settlement process, before finalizing the settlement. ) On the day agreement is reached, the terms and dollar adjustments of the resolved issues are documented on the FT Session Report.
